user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_ClearDeferredRetcode:
```c
void UT_ClearDeferredRetcode(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr;

    while (true)
    {
        StubPtr = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETVAL_CONFIG_DEFERRED);
        if (StubPtr == NULL)
        {
            break;
        }
        UT_ClearStubEntry(StubPtr);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
while (true)
    {
        StubPtr = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETVAL_CONFIG_DEFERRED);
        if (StubPtr == NULL)
        {
            break;
        }
        UT_ClearStubEntry(StubPtr);
    }
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the loop condition is 'while (true)' but the loop contains a runtime 'break' when StubPtr == NULL, so both the call to UT_GetStubEntry and the call to UT_ClearStubEntry are reachable depending on runtime values. A hypothetical violation would occur if UT_GetStubEntry were provably a compile-time constant that always returns NULL (e.g., a macro or inline that expands to NULL), which would make the UT_ClearStubEntry call unreachable, but that is not shown in the fragment.
